data.author: Couerdelion
data.content: Not sure I understand how this works.  If the plan is to complete £2m of buyback today (4% of total shares) wouldn't that push the share price up beyond the maximum price they can pay thereby undercutting the supply of shares to repurchase.  Maybe there's some equilibrium point I can't quite picture yet. At least we know the plan and the amount so that ought to be positive for the SP, right?

data.author: Couerdelion
data.content: Afternoon pullback was a little disappointing but give this a little more time. We have something like 70% of the MCap backed by cash here so you're not even paying for inventory less trade liabilities let alone any capacity to make money in the future. It's making profits now and these are prices you'd pay for a company that can't cover its running costs.

data.author: Couerdelion
data.content: Fair enough. For my part, I squirrelled away a few of these in my 2025/26 ISA though recouped around 60% of the costs through selling the ones I bought around two weeks ago in my GIA. Took a bit of time to get the right prices and I was overweight for around 24 hours but target thresholds are only rules of thumb and I have the long term confidence in the company that I don't have any problem being stuck with a few extra shares if Trump were to come out with another brainfart. I would perhaps consider the target audience of Naked Wines. These are quality wines that WINE will be selling to the comfortably-affluent American rather than the bud-drinking core Trump base. For a comparison, maybe look at MKS and how their shares reacted this week, and you'll perhaps see why WINE will have some level of protection from the trade winds unleashed these last few weeks. The biggest threat may even be from a potential oversupply of better wines if the US finds it has too much but those tend to operate in a very different market and I suspect the high-quality wines from California et.al. would react here by holding back supply rather than flooding the market.

data.author: Couerdelion
data.content: Fair enough. For my part, I squirrelled away a few of these in my 2025/26 ISA though recouped around 60% of the costs through selling the ones I bought around two weeks ago in my GIA. Took a bit of time to get the right prices and I was overweight for around 24 hours but target thresholds are only rules of thumb and I have the long term confidence in the company that I don't have any problem being stuck with a few extra shares if Trump were to come out with another brainfart. I would perhaps consider the target audience of Naked Wines. These are quality wines that WINE will be selling to the comfortably-affluent American rather than the bud-drinking core Trump base. For a comparison, maybe look at MKS and how their shares reacted this week, and you'll perhaps see why WINE will have some level of protection from the trade winds unleashed these last few weeks. The biggest threat may even be from a potential oversupply of better wines if the US finds it has too much but those tend to operate in a very different market and I suspect the high-quality wines from California et.al. would react here by holding back supply rather than flooding the market.

data.author: Couerdelion

I found some room in this year's ISA for around 4000 shares and they look good to hold for the medium term. I sold some of the shares in the GIA today, largely to manage exposures, so missed out on a little bonus from the late afternoon price rise. I'm not entirely convinced that the broader market is pricing correctly the Trump tariffs so wanted to top up the coffers for round 2 of proceedings.   Round 1 was perfectly timed for ISA investors.

data.author: ValuePlayer1
data.content: Just to add, this is the front page of their note on WINE: Investors need to pay attention – Naked Wines has turned a corner, it is FCF positive and there is a plan to achieve three things: (1) significantly build cash on the B/S (>£100m over the next five years), (2) return the business to 5-10% revenue growth by the back-end of the plan while underpinning EBITDA at c.£10m in the near-term and (3) commit to distributing this cash to shareholders. All this is being achieved while improving returns, and deploying a new marketing plan that offers the opportunity to deliver sustainable growth. With cash (c.£33m on the B/S now + selling excess inventory of £40m) much greater than the current market cap of c.£45m we see huge upside to the share price. Hence, we increase TP to 150p from 50p. BUY

data.author: Couerdelion
data.content: The closing price was exactly what I was asking about.  You're now in a situation where the company is offering to buyback the shares from investors at a discount to the closing price and why would a seller agree to that if they can get more directly from the market.

data.author: gotabesirius
data.content: It's a book build so basically offering to buy whatever sellers are willing to offload around current price. Guessing they have a seller in the market hence recent weakness. Regardless we'll find out at the end of the day how much of the £2m they were able to fill at circa 71p

data.author: Couerdelion
data.content: As regards shares held in treasury, whether these are cancelled or not doesn't make a great deal of difference (though it is good housekeeping).  Any dividends for those shares would not be paid (company is effectively paying a dividend to itself) and they would not carry any voting rights.  So effectively they disappear.

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: Couerdelion, Same here. My question is, if the shares are not cancelled and instead put in treasury, does the issued share capital not remain the same? TWK - Puzzled

data.author: Couerdelion
data.content: Not sure I understand how this works.  If the plan is to complete £2m of buyback today (4% of total shares) wouldn't that push the share price up beyond the maximum price they can pay thereby undercutting the supply of shares to repurchase.  Maybe there's some equilibrium point I can't quite picture yet. At least we know the plan and the amount so that ought to be positive for the SP, right?

data.author: Couerdelion
data.content: Afternoon pullback was a little disappointing but give this a little more time. We have something like 70% of the MCap backed by cash here so you're not even paying for inventory less trade liabilities let alone any capacity to make money in the future. It's making profits now and these are prices you'd pay for a company that can't cover its running costs.

data.author: Couerdelion
data.content: Fair enough. For my part, I squirrelled away a few of these in my 2025/26 ISA though recouped around 60% of the costs through selling the ones I bought around two weeks ago in my GIA. Took a bit of time to get the right prices and I was overweight for around 24 hours but target thresholds are only rules of thumb and I have the long term confidence in the company that I don't have any problem being stuck with a few extra shares if Trump were to come out with another brainfart. I would perhaps consider the target audience of Naked Wines. These are quality wines that WINE will be selling to the comfortably-affluent American rather than the bud-drinking core Trump base. For a comparison, maybe look at MKS and how their shares reacted this week, and you'll perhaps see why WINE will have some level of protection from the trade winds unleashed these last few weeks. The biggest threat may even be from a potential oversupply of better wines if the US finds it has too much but those tend to operate in a very different market and I suspect the high-quality wines from California et.al. would react here by holding back supply rather than flooding the market.

I sold some of the shares in the GIA today, largely to manage exposures, so missed out on a little bonus from the late afternoon price rise. I'm not entirely convinced that the broader market is pricing correctly the Trump tariffs so wanted to top up the coffers for round 2 of proceedings.   Round 1 was perfectly timed for ISA investors.

data.author: ValuePlayer1
data.content: Just to add, this is the front page of their note on WINE: Investors need to pay attention – Naked Wines has turned a corner, it is FCF positive and there is a plan to achieve three things: (1) significantly build cash on the B/S (>£100m over the next five years), (2) return the business to 5-10% revenue growth by the back-end of the plan while underpinning EBITDA at c.£10m in the near-term and (3) commit to distributing this cash to shareholders. All this is being achieved while improving returns, and deploying a new marketing plan that offers the opportunity to deliver sustainable growth. With cash (c.£33m on the B/S now + selling excess inventory of £40m) much greater than the current market cap of c.£45m we see huge upside to the share price. Hence, we increase TP to 150p from 50p. BUY

data.author: Couerdelion
data.content: The closing price was exactly what I was asking about.  You're now in a situation where the company is offering to buyback the shares from investors at a discount to the closing price and why would a seller agree to that if they can get more directly from the market.

data.author: gotabesirius
data.content: It's a book build so basically offering to buy whatever sellers are willing to offload around current price. Guessing they have a seller in the market hence recent weakness. Regardless we'll find out at the end of the day how much of the £2m they were able to fill at circa 71p

data.author: Couerdelion
data.content: As regards shares held in treasury, whether these are cancelled or not doesn't make a great deal of difference (though it is good housekeeping).  Any dividends for those shares would not be paid (company is effectively paying a dividend to itself) and they would not carry any voting rights.  So effectively they disappear.

data.author: thewakokid
data.content: Couerdelion, Same here. My question is, if the shares are not cancelled and instead put in treasury, does the issued share capital not remain the same? TWK - Puzzled

data.author: Couerdelion
data.content: Not sure I understand how this works.  If the plan is to complete £2m of buyback today (4% of total shares) wouldn't that push the share price up beyond the maximum price they can pay thereby undercutting the supply of shares to repurchase.  Maybe there's some equilibrium point I can't quite picture yet. At least we know the plan and the amount so that ought to be positive for the SP, right?

data.author: Couerdelion
data.content: Afternoon pullback was a little disappointing but give this a little more time. We have something like 70% of the MCap backed by cash here so you're not even paying for inventory less trade liabilities let alone any capacity to make money in the future. It's making profits now and these are prices you'd pay for a company that can't cover its running costs.
